summary.para: Converts IPv4 addresses to their number value.

Converts one or more IPv4 address values (in the address family) to a number value representing the address. Though using this module indicates that you have a reason for it already, this conversion is most often used for comparison or data storage.

example.code: PS:\ > Get-DhcpServerv4Scope -ComputerName Server01 | Get-DhcpServerv4Lease -ComputerName Server01 | Convert-IPv4ToNumber 2887165501 2887165502 2887165503 [ additional rows omitted ]
example.para: Values can be piped into the cmdlet by value as well as by property name.

summary.para: The IPv4 address value(s) to convert to numbers. The values provided must be in the InterNetwork (IPv4) address family: values cannot be greater than [IPAddress]::Broadcast (255.255.255.255) or less than [IPAddress]::Any (0.0.0.0).
Converts a number to an IPv4 address.
Converts a number ([double] or [long]) to an IPv4 address. Any number value between 0 and 4294967295 can be converted to an IPv4 address.

example.code: PS:\ > Convert-NumberToIPv4 -InputObject 3232248323 Address : 53651648 AddressFamily : InterNetwork ScopeId : IsIPv6Multicast : False IsIPv6LinkLocal : False IsIPv6SiteLocal : False IsIPv6Teredo : False IsIPv4MappedToIPv6 : False IPAddressToString : 192.168.50.3

PS:\ > 3232248320..3232248323 | Convert-NumberToIPv4 | Select AddressFamily, IPAddressToString AddressFamily IPAddressToString ------------- ----------------- InterNetwork 192.168.50.0 InterNetwork 192.168.50.1 InterNetwork 192.168.50.2 InterNetwork 192.168.50.3
example.para: Values can be piped into the cmdlet by value as well as by property name.

summary.para: The number value(s) of any IPAddress(es) to convert. Each value will be converted to an . The value cannot be less than 0 or greater than 4294967295.
Gets the IP subnet range of a given address and CIDR or subnet mask.

Identifies and returns the subnet range of a given address and corresponding CIDR or subnet mask. Returns the broadcast address (the end of the range), the subnet address (often the scope id - the beginning of the range), and the subnet mask.

example.code:
PS:\ > Get-IPv4SubnetRange -CidrNotation '172.22.78.0/24' | Select *
CidrNotation : 172.22.78.0/24 SubnetMask : 255.255.255.0 NetworkAddress : 172.22.78.0 BroadcastAddress : 172.22.78.255 StartRange : 172.22.78.1 EndRange : 172.22.78.254 Range : { 172.22.78.1, 172.22.78.2, 172.22.78.3 ... } IPAddress : 172.22.78.0

summary.para: The IPv4 network address of the subnet; for example, '192.168.150.0'.

The CIDR value of the subnet; for example, the '24' in '192.168.150.0/24'. This value is converted to a subnet with the equivalent number of bits set to true: a CIDR value of 24 will result in a subnet with binary value '11111111.11111111.11111111.00000000', equivalent to '255.255.255.0'.
The mask of the subnet, such as '255.255.255.0'.
The network address and CIDR separated by a forward slash: for example, '192.168.150.0/24'. This value is split and parsed to determine the network address and subnet mask.

member.name: T:PSSharp.Commands.StartPingJobCommand

summary.para: Initiates a job that waits for a successful reply.
Starts a , which pings a destination (host name or IP address) until the ping returns successfully, at which time the job concludes.

member.example:
PS:\> Start-PingJob localhost Id Name PSJobTypeName State HasMoreData Location Command -- ---- ------------- ----- ----------- -------- ------- 1 Job1 PingJob Completed True localhost Start-PingJob localhost
PS:\> Get-Job | Receive-Job ComputerName Address ------------ ------- localhost ::1
A job started on the localhost will return immedately in a successful state.
PS:\> Start-PingJob -ComputerName Server02 | Wait-Job | Remove-Job Piping a PingJob directly into wait-job will pause the script until the target returns a successful ping response.

PS:\> $Servers = 'Server01','Server02' PS:\> Stop-Computer -ComputerName $Servers -Force PS:\> Start-Sleep -Seconds 90 # wait for computers to shut down PS:\> Start-PingJob -ComputerName $Servers | Receive-Job -Wait -AutoRemoveJob | ForEach-Object { Invoke-Command -ComputerName $_.ComputerName -ScriptBlock $ServerStartupScript }
This example demonstrates starting ping jobs for multiple computers and using the results to wait for a computer to come online before running a script on the computers. Note that a ping reply may indicate success before the WSMan or similar remoting services have started on a computer.

summary.para: The ComputerName or IP address that will be pinged.
